docs.lead_paragraph: RICHENTHAL--Arthur. October 11, 2007. Beloved husband of the late Vivian. Adoring father of Donald, David and Susan. Cherished grandfather of Daniel, Matthew, Kate, and Julliette. Loving companion of Joan Easton. Service Sunday October 14, 11:30am at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave. at 81st St. In lieu of flowers contributions may be made to the Vivian Richenthal Pulmonary Institute at Mount Sinai Hospital . RICHENTHAL--Arthur. The Trustees, Faculty and Staff of The Mount Sinai Medical Center mourn the passing of Arthur Richenthal, an outstanding philanthropist and dedicated member of The Mount Sinai Boards of Trustees. Mr. Richenthal's commitment to patient care at Mount Sinai was extraordinary, and included the creation of the Vivian Richenthal Institute for Pulmonary and Critical Care Medicine and support for many other health and scientific programs. We extend our heartfelt condolences to his sons, Donald and David, his daughter, Susan, his companion, Joan Easton, and the entire family. Peter W. May, Chairman of the Boards of Trustees, Kenneth L. Davis, M.D., President and CEO, The Mount Sinai Medical Center RICHENTHAL--Arthur. The Gaisman Division of Pulmonary, Critical Care and Sleep Medicine of the Mount Sinai Medical Center and the Vivian Richenthal Research Institute deeply mourn the death of our extraordinary friend and advisor, Arthur Richenthal. His strong support and wisdom has enabled us to make major contributions in the battle against disabling Lung Disease. Victims of lung cancer, fibrosing lung diseases and the World Trade Center catastrophe have benefited from his commitment to research and patient care. He was a valuable, proud New York City treasure who had a rare blend of intelligence, incisiveness, wisdom, warmth, and humility. Our deepest sympathy to his children and grandchildren. Our staff, patients and all New York join them in grieving the loss of this pillar of our families. Michael C. Iannuzzi, M.D. Alvin S. Teirstein, M.D.

docs.lead_paragraph: The idea that illness is good for children is wrong. In part, the idea of “good sickness” is a throwback to a now disproved version of the “hygiene hypothesis.”
